No. She... Never mind.
Picasso
Do you know Pablo Picasso?
Who doesn't know him?
A dirty fraud selling his "paintings" for piles of money! Do you know that some of them go for THOUSANDS OF DOLLARS?!
Rafael, Michelangelo, Leonardo di ser Piero da Vinci! THEY were artists!
So you're not familiar with Picasso's work?
No, not really. Somebody told me that Picasso was actually able to paint well when he was young.
But then, suddenly, he started to do strange things. Boxes and eyes everywhere. Maybe he had a stroke?
Change the subject
I think that's enough for now.
No, that doesn't really interest me.
But of course.
Family
Where is she from? Who were her parents?
Her father was a wealthy British salesman. Her mother died in childbirth.
She had an outstanding education but was a lonely child, they say. Her father was away on business most of the time.
I know how she feels. For many years, my father's career was also more important than me.
shocked
Don't say that, child! Your father paid for the life you now live.
Did Lady Westmacott's father marry again?
Yes. A woman fifteen years his junior. She didn't really care for the child. She was something of a "high society lady".
She made the headlines with her antics more often than the family would have liked.
Journey
And what does an elderly lady like her want in Egypt?
Do you know what the lady wants to do in Cairo?
I couldn't really say. She was there many times with her husband, an archaeologist.
He died a long time ago.
I heard something about a reception at the Egyptian Museum?
Yes, for the Eyes of the Sphinx. Or rather, for the Eye.
But I don't think she'd go to Cairo just for that. She usually stays away from official events.
Didn't participate in the literary scene, either. Always stayed as far away as possible from high society. Probably because of her stepmother.
Novels
And her novels? How did she come to be a writer?
Why did she want to become a writer?
In interviews she always mentions her French tutor who encouraged her to write when she was a child.
After some poems and short stories she began to write detective novels-with great success.
The rest is history. The experts are arguing whether she or Shakespeare has sold more books.
Although she doesn't receive the same deference.
That's true. But her books are much more innovative and extraordinary than people generally give her credit for.
Lady Westmacott
Lovely concert, wasn't it?
You only heard the end. It was really wonderful!
All the more curious that Lady Westmacott embarrassed Mr. Kreutzer like that, don't you think?
I have no idea what got into her. They say she's a difficult person. But this...
Maybe it's the privilege of famous people to be a bit strange from time to time.
When I still was a young sailor, Enrico Caruso was a passenger on our ship! And he...
interrupts him
I think she's fascinating. She's achieved so much. All by herself.
Lady Westmacott? Oh yes, that's true. The most successful writer in the world.
Do you know more about her?
Everything! I'm her biggest fan! What do you want to know?
Lady Westmacott
About Lady Westmacott... There's still something that interests me...
What do you want to know?
Say goodbye
I just realized that I need to be going.
I'm going to go have a look around.
All right.
I hope I'll see you at the reception tonight-ten o'clock.
You won't give an old salty sea dog the brush-off will you?
I'll be there.
Wonderful!
He's sweating profusely. Burst capillaries and a sweet odor.
I hope the crew doesn't take the captain for a role model and that they stay sober for the rest of the trip.
Hello, Captain DiConti!
Miss Mayers!
How nice to see you. You look beautiful. We missed you at dinner!
I was in my cabin. I... didn't feel very well.
Oh, I hope you're feeling better.
Captain DiConti?
Yes?
I don't know why... People just seem to open up to me. Is that a blessing or a curse?
It must be horrible to look back bitterly at the end of one's life. Especially if it could have been a great life.
I'll leave him alone with his thoughts.
Talk to Lady Westmacott
AD
I've got a puzzle for you!
Why do you always bombard me with strange questions? I can't imagine why.
Oh, come on, you're the queen of mysteries!
Well? What is it then?
A monogram. A capital "A" with a small "D" on the bottom... Who does it belong to?
Someone on the ship?
No, no one on the ship.
I don't know. Whose is it?
I don't know either!
It doesn't make much sense to ask a riddle if you don't know the answer. Wouldn't you agree?
Actually... I'd say that it doesn't make sense to ask someone a riddle if you DO know the answer.
stunned, approving
Touché.
Albrecht Dürer
Are you interested in art?
Not really. I'm more interested in real life, in people.
So you don't know Albrecht Dürer?
Just because I'm not interested in art doesn't mean that I'm ignorant.
What can you tell me about him?
Books, my dear, books!
In them you'll find the answers to all your questions. Even the most foolish ones!
I bet you don't know anything about him and just want to cover it up.
Ah! You want to appeal to my honor! Too obvious, I'm afraid.
Buonarroti
I saw a sign in Venice. It said "Buonarroti". Do you know what it means?
I'm sorry, I don't speak Italian.
The violinist
Mr. Kreutzer possesses impressive technique, don't you think?
He certainly does.
His numerous playmates in Austria can tell you more about it than I.
You mean, Mr. Kreutzer is a womanizer?
I'm not talking about cheap skirts. I'm talking about expensive clothes.
A man like him needs funds to support his lifestyle.
loud
Just go over to him, my dear! Tell the maestro that your family is wealthy.
loud
You have everything he's looking for: money and a pretty face!
angry
Hold your tongue!
shocked, upset
Mr. Kreutzer! Lady Westmacott! Please!
loud
Or did you have your eye on me, Mr. Kreutzer? Old, yes-but rich!
[The violinist stands up angrily, leaves the salon quickly.]
hissing
Jezebel!
Mr. Kreutzer! Maestro!
[The captain doesn't really know whether he should look after the writer or the violinist. He looks briefly at the writer but then he follows the violinist.]
content
That's better.
rather to herself, bitterly
Freeloader.
Guernica
Does "Guernica" mean anything to you?
Why are you asking me all these strange questions?
Do you usually ask strangers random questions?
I... I'm curious. How shall I learn if I don't ask?
Pick up a book.
New York
Have you ever been to New York?
For the love of God, what would I do there? We have the original York in England. That's quite enough for me.
So you don't know the heraldic animal of New York?
No. Probably an eagle. It's all eagles over there.
Nefertiti
I hear you're well-versed in Egyptian history, Lady Westmacott. Can you tell me anything about Nefertiti?
A queen. The main wife of Akhenaten.
Did she have a favorite animal?
stunned
What a strange question!
I, um, just heard that they really adored cats in ancient Egypt.
That's true. But I don't know whether Nefertiti had any special affinity for animals.
Are there any famous works of art depicting her?
Oh, yes. The bust of Nefertiti. One of the most beautiful ancient Egyptian sculptures! I saw it years ago in London.
So the bust is located in England?
No. It was discovered in 1912 in Tell el-Amarna by a German archaeologist and brought to Germany.
I'm not sure where it is today. Ask the baroness-she's the expert on museums here!
Picasso
It must be exciting to meet all the world's famous and powerful people.
I stay away as far as possible from high society. Too shallow. Too boring.
But some of them must be exciting! Have you ever met Picasso?
Pff! They told him that he's a genius so often that he actually started to believe it himself.
But his paintings are impressive. Guernica, for example.
Well, it certainly is big, I have to give him that.
Didn't he have to flee from Spain?
Yes, from the fascists. But not just him. Many of his paintings as well. If I remember correctly, Guernica is currently on display in the Museum of Modern Art in New York.
He bequeathed it to a future Spanish republic.
And until then, it stays in New York?
Yes. It's been there for years now.
Journey
Is this your first trip on the Lydia?
That's quite enough. Life is too short for conversations like this.
I do wish that rather delightful Swiss policeman had come along.
I heard you had an "interesting" trip on the train.
It was thrilling!
I'm hoping for an encore! Perhaps in Cairo...
Acting
You know... I'm not planning on throwing myself at a man.
I'm not planning on throwing myself at a man.
I'm glad to hear it.
You have to work. Earn you own money.
I will! My grades are excellent and I want to study acting in New York.
snidely
None of my books has ever been made into a good film. The stories were twisted, shortened and simplified so that even the dimmest fellow could follow them.
I want to do theater. And travel. I speak three languages!
That would be three more than most people your age can speak.
Do what you have to do. But stay away from bad men!
Freeloader
You and Mr. Kreutzer... You seem to know each other?
Not really. But I know his type.
Parasites who cling to the rich and famous and suck them dry.
The young, misunderstood painter. The innovative writer who writes books that no one wants to read. The musical talent that has to be supported.
The ladies and gentlemen of high society let the others use them and call themselves "patrons". Another word for "fool".
Didn't you finance archaeological excavations in the Near East and Egypt?
angry
For my husband! And I was there myself. I catalogued items for him and I didn't show him off like a trophy at cocktail parties.
grim, lost in thought
But my son was one of them.
grim, lost in thought
The worst kind. The kind that sucks not only the money but also the life right out of a person.
Say goodbye
Err. Oh, nothing.
sarcastically
Do feel free to continue pestering me, child!
May I take my leave?
As a matter of fact, I insist.
You may.
Prejudices
Are you easily prejudiced at your age?
In my long experience, there's often a core of truth at the center of every prejudice.
Prejudice is the reason of fools.
Was that written in the book you once read?
Oh, I've read many books. Good books.
But not my books, you mean to say?
You're a writer?
smiling
What can I do for you? Miss...
Mayers.
Lady Westmacott never let anyone tell her what to do. They say she was a stubborn one. And today she's one of the richest women in the world.
A wonderful concert, wasn't it?
[The writer looks disdainfully at the young woman.]
I wouldn't have expected you to be a connoisseur of classical music.
Because I'm American?
Because you're young. And friendly and radiant. Someone like you doesn't have to know a lot to get along well in life.
Lady Westmacott?
Yes?
The lady is not a fan of shallow conversation, which I respect.
I shouldn't talk to her unless I have something serious to say.
